name: Schinzel's hypothesis H
rephrased: There are infinitely many integers t such that for a set of polynomials with integer coefficients, each irreducible and positive for large t, all these polynomials evaluated at t are prime.
implication_form: If there exists a set of polynomials with integer coefficients, each irreducible and positive for large t, then there are infinitely many integers t such that all these polynomials evaluated at t are prime.
explained: Schinzel's hypothesis H is a profound conjecture in number theory concerning the existence of infinitely many integer solutions to systems of equations defined by polynomials. It states that if one has a finite set of irreducible (primitive) polynomials with integer coefficients, positive leading coefficients, and such that for every prime p, there does not exist a fixed residue class modulo p that all polynomials simultaneously avoid (i.e., no fixed prime p divides all values of the polynomials for some integer input), then there exists a positive integer n such that all the polynomials evaluated at n yield prime numbers. Furthermore, there should be infinitely many such integers n. This conjecture is a generalization that subsumes many other famous conjectures about prime numbers, such as the twin prime conjecture (which corresponds to the polynomial set {x, x+2}).
